I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed grants 
to the Independent State of Samoa, the Kingdom of Tonga, Tuvalu, and the Republic of Vanuatu 
for the additional financing of the Systems Strengthening for Effective Coverage of New Vaccines 
in the Pacific Project under the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility (APVAX).1 
 
2.  The original project adopts a regional approach to improving immunization outcomes by 
introducing three vaccines in Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu. It supports the countries in 
(i) pooling the procurement of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine, the pneumococcal 
conjugate vaccine (PCV), and the rotavirus vaccine through the United Nations Children's Fund 
(UNICEF); (ii) strengthening primary health care and the capacity to deliver vaccination programs; 
and (iii) increasing community awareness and the population's knowledge of and attitude toward 
vaccines.  The  project  will  reduce  the  burden  and  minimize  outbreaks  related  to  vaccine-
preventable diseases, integrate immunization programs into broader health systems, and improve 
access  to  primary  health  services.  As  a  response  to  the  coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19) 
pandemic, the governments of Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu have been preparing for the 
imminent arrival of COVID-19 vaccines, and have requested additional financing from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to further strengthen immunization programs and prepare for the 
vaccine rollout.2 The additional financing will build on the original project to support the four 
governments in meeting their urgent needs. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Original project. ADB approved the original project for $25.1 million on 8 November 2018 
(footnote 1). It comprises a loan of $2.25 million (Vanuatu) from ADB’s concessional ordinary 
capital resources, and grants of $7.50 million (Samoa), $3.85 million (Tonga), $2.50 million 
(Tuvalu), and $9.00 million (Vanuatu) from ADB’s Special Funds resources. The governments are 
providing combined counterpart funding of $4.56 million. The loan and grant agreements for 
Vanuatu were signed on 28 February 2019 and became effective on 1 July 2019. The grant 
agreement for Samoa was signed on 21 January 2019 and became effective on 1 July 2019; the 
grant agreement for Tonga was signed on 29 November 2018 and became effective on 14 August 
2019; and the grant agreement for Tuvalu was signed on 12 December 2018 and became 
effective on 29 August 2019. The closing date for the loan and grants is 31 May 2024. The 
ministries of finance in Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu are the executing agencies, and the 
respective ministries of health (MOHs) are the implementing agencies for the project. All four 
developing member countries (DMC) have signed agreements with UNICEF to procure new 
vaccines and strengthen immunization. They share a regional project management unit with 
separate contracts and local consultants in each country to support the project's implementation.  
 
4.  Project performance. The original project is rated for attention as of the fourth quarter of 
2020,3 primarily because of initial delays in contract awards and disbursements, which are being 
addressed. The performance of the project is considered satisfactory in other aspects.

Manila. The COVID-19 outbreak occurred in 2020. The Pacific Department confirmed that the 2020 resource

(i)  Delivery of expected outputs. The implementation is rated on track to deliver all 
expected outputs (para. 13). For output 1, the UNICEF Vaccine Independence 
Initiative (VII) agreements have been amended, and the VII credit line increased 
in all four countries to procure three new vaccines, i.e., the HPV vaccine, the PCV, 
and the rotavirus vaccine (para. 14). For output 2, UNICEF output agreements 
have been signed, and initial activities for health system strengthening have taken 
place in all four countries, including forecasting vaccine procurement, updating 
national immunization policies with gender considerations, updating child health 
immunization cards, and supporting integrated outreach programs. Delays in 
implementation are expected, however, because of the ongoing response to the 
COVID-19 pandemic and associated travel restrictions (para. 15). For output 3, 
community engagement activities commenced in the first quarter of 2021. UNICEF 
is seeking to integrate these with ongoing risk communication activities (para. 16).  
(ii)  Contract awards and disbursements. Actual contract awards total $12.0 million 
(47.9% of the project amount) and disbursements are $6.9 million (27.4%).4 
The delays in contract awards (76% against 2020 projections) and disbursements 
(65% against 2020 projections) are attributable to the relative inexperience of the 
implementing agencies with ADB-financed projects. The situation improved when 
a  project  management  firm  was  recruited  in  February  2020  to  assist  the 
implementing agencies on procurement, multiple withdrawal applications, and 
disbursements. There are currently no cost overruns. 
(iii)  Financial management covenants. The original project is on track on compliance 
with financial management covenants.  
(iv)  Safeguard policy requirements. All safeguards covenants under the original 
project are being complied with.  
(v)  Management of risks. Project risks are being managed successfully through 
(a) the recruitment of a project management firm to support the implementing 
agencies in financial reporting and procurement; and (b) the update of the UNICEF 
vaccine  agreements  by  all  four  countries  early  in  project  implementation, 
highlighting their continued commitment to the partnership with UNICEF and to 
improving immunization.  
 
5.  Additional financing. The governments of Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu have 
incurred considerable costs to prevent the entry of COVID-19 through travel restrictions, 5 while 
mitigating the pandemic’s effects on their economies. Additional financing is proposed to expand 
the scope of the original project, i.e., to include the introduction of COVID-19 vaccines, which will 
enable the gradual reopening of borders and economies, and reestablish the free movement of 
people both nationally and internationally. Since the regulatory approvals and supply of COVID-
19 vaccines to eligible countries under the COVID-19 Vaccines Global Access (COVAX) and 
Advance Market Commitment (AMC) mechanisms—are still in progress, the exact vaccine type 
and delivery timeline remains to be confirmed. The additional financing will further strengthen the 
health systems’ routine immunization programs and community engagement activities. With 
COVID-19 vaccines expected to be available from Q2 2021 through COVAX, Pacific countries 
need to prepare their health systems to safely introduce any such vaccine.6 The additional scope 
is a high priority for the governments as they plan to open their borders to travel, and is consistent 
with the original project in strengthening health systems and increasing immunization coverage.  
 
 
4  As of 31 December 2020. 
5  As of 16 March 2021, Samoa had reported four imported cases of COVID-19 and Vanuatu three cases, all of which 
have recovered. Tonga and Tuvalu remain free of COVID-19. Cumulatively across Pacific DMCs, 2,364 confirmed 
cases and 28 deaths have been reported. 
6  COVAX is co-led by Gavi, the vaccine alliance; the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations; and the World 
Health Organization (WHO). It was established in April 2020 to accelerate global access to COVID-19 vaccines.

3 
6.  The additional financing will benefit from the established regional project management unit 
and a stronger partnership with UNICEF on immunization systems and vaccine procurement. The 
introduction of COVID-19 vaccines through the additional financing will rely on procurement 
arrangements established under the ongoing project, supported by measures to strengthen 
immunization  systems  and  community  engagement.  Initial  delays  in  contract  awards  and 
disbursements  can  also  be  minimized  by  using  the  original  project’s  implementation 
arrangements. The additional financing will support the overall project in achieving the outcome 
of increased national immunization coverage. No cost overruns exist at present. No new major or 
complex contracts are proposed. The COVID-19 vaccines will be procured through UNICEF, the 
lead procurement agency under COVAX.7 
 
7.  Impact of the pandemic. Growth with COVID-19 is expected to be lower than pre-
COVID-19 projections in all four countries, and fiscal balances are set to worsen in FY2021 
(Table 1).8 COVID-19-related border restrictions have severely hurt local commercial activities, 
especially tourism and construction, and many businesses are facing financial difficulties and 
laying off workers. The pandemic, coupled with the impacts of cyclones Harold and Tino in 2020, 
has led to supply chain bottlenecks and disruptions in production, and lowered tax revenues.

8.  All four governments have declared and remain in states of emergency in connection with 
the pandemic as of March 2021, and introduced measures to control the potential spread of the 
disease, such as (i) implementing border and travel restrictions, local lockdowns, and social 
distancing rules for mass gatherings; and (ii) strengthening health systems to prepare for and 
respond  to  COVID-19  through  a  national  COVID-19  response  plan,  or  equivalent.  The 
governments are now looking at the introduction of a COVID-19 vaccine as another key measure 
to limit and control the pandemic. 
 
9.  Government response (needs assessment and vaccination allocation plan). The four 
DMCs conducted needs assessments of their immunization systems for the introduction of 
COVID-19 vaccines through the Vaccine Introduction Readiness Assessment Tool. The World 
Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF, as well as ADB, supported these assessments in the 
areas of planning and coordination, vaccine procurement and financing, service delivery, training 
and supervision, cold chain, supply chain logistics, monitoring and evaluation, safety surveillance,

cold  chains,  monitoring  and  surveillance  systems,  integrated  outreach,  and  community 
engagement—are aligned to the support proposed under the additional financing, and indicative 
support from other development partners. The DMCs have also committed to prioritizing COVID-
19  vaccines  access  for  vulnerable  groups  and  managing  medical  waste  from  vaccines 
deployment in accordance with WHO guidelines. All four DMCs demonstrate compliance with the 
access criteria of APVAX (Table 2).10

10.  Development  partner  coordination.  ADB  is  an  active  member  of  several  partner 
coordination platforms. Development partners acted swiftly to support Pacific islands in mitigating 
COVID-19  impacts.  Since  the  outbreak  of  the  pandemic,  development  support  has  been 
coordinated through weekly meetings of the Joint Incident Management Team, chaired by WHO 
Pacific, with subgroups to coordinate on specific technical areas of support, such as the vaccines 
pillar to coordinate the introduction of the COVID-19 vaccine. Discussions around readiness 
assessments and technical support enabled Pacific DMCs to identify priority gaps, needs, and 
issues in planning for COVID-19 vaccine procurement, access, and delivery. Development 
partners are also part of the partner coordination pillar to share opportunities for collaboration and 
financial support for vaccines, and for information sharing on COVID-19 vaccine initiatives.11 
Under the operational support and logistics pillar, partners such as ADB provided support for 
medical and personal protective equipment, supplies for testing through GeneXpert distribution,

11.  Promoting procurement of safe and effective vaccines. The additional financing 
applies the eligibility criteria for ADB’s COVID-19 vaccine support.12 The COVID-19 vaccines will 
be procured under the project by UNICEF. They will be selected through COVAX on behalf of 
Samoa,  Tonga,  Tuvalu,  and  Vanuatu,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  vaccine  eligibility  criteria 
(footnote 12). This will ensure that vaccines being procured promote public health safety, reduce 
deaths and disease burdens, and minimize societal and economic disruption from the pandemic. 
Letters from the four DMC governors are attached, confirming commitment to the implementation 
of each DMC’s COVID-19 vaccination allocation plan and adherence to ADB’s criteria for vaccine 
support.13  
 
12.  Strategic alignment and modality. The overall project continues to be aligned with 
national health strategies in all four DMCs, through its commitment to improving public health and 
infection prevention control.14 It is in line with ADB’s Strategy 2030 priorities of reducing poverty 
and inequalities; accelerating progress in gender equality; tackling climate change, building 
climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental  sustainability;  strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity; and fostering regional cooperation and integration.15 It is 
also consistent with the Pacific Approach, 2016–2020 priority of managing risks through stronger 
health systems.16 The design of the additional financing follows the project investment component 
of the APVAX policy, and the project applies the diligence, access, and vaccine eligibility 
requirements, as well as the policy variations applicable to APVAX projects (Table 2). The project 
will support the procurement of eligible COVID-19 vaccines, and help strengthen health systems 
and increase community awareness. Procurement will be through UNICEF, the lead procurement 
agency under COVAX. All vaccines procured by UNICEF should conform to WHO standards, 
such as prequalification, or be granted WHO's Emergency Use Listing.17 
 
B.  Project Description

Development Goal 3);18 and (iii) SARS-Cov2 virus’ spread, morbidity and mortality reduced, and 
confidence  of  citizens  restored.  It  will  adopt  the  same  outcome  (increased  immunization

14.  Output 1: Regional vaccine procurement strengthened. ADB will continue to support 
Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu in procuring the HPV and rotavirus vaccines as well as the 
PCV through UNICEF’s VII. In Tonga, it will also finance the measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine 
from year 2 through phased counterpart financing, replacing the current measles and rubella 
vaccine.22 The original project is also supporting the procurement of cold chain equipment and 
associated supplies, with performance, quality, and safety certification recommended by WHO 
and UNICEF; microplanning in at least 90% of health facilities; and national vaccine forecasting, 
which  includes  emergency  preparedness  planning  and  maintenance  of  a  buffer  stock. 
Procurement capacity building will contribute to more effective planning and procurement of 
health commodities. Under the additional financing, this output will be expanded to include 
(i) procurement through UNICEF—the lead procurement agency of COVAX-allocated COVID-19 
vaccines for Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu—when one of the APVAX-eligible vaccines 
becomes available through COVAX allocations;23 and (ii) the upgrade of cold chain capacities, as 
required, to accommodate the introduction of the COVID-19 vaccine. The additional financing 
proposed is to target the financing of any cost-shared COVID-19 vaccines to up to 20% of the 
population at the onset, in alignment with the 20% allocation under COVAX, with budget for up to 
70% of the population as COVAX-allocated doses are made available in the future. ADB has been 
one of the leading financiers of routine vaccines in the four DMCs, and will aim to further expand 
this support for the roll-out of the COVID-19 vaccines. 
 
15.  Output 2: Health systems strengthened. The overall project will continue to strengthen 
primary health care and reduce inequities in access to health services. The original project 
supports  (i)  the  updating  of  immunization  and  cold  chain  policies, guidelines, and  training 
materials; (ii) the training of health workers through workshops and on-the-job practice in vaccine 
administration,  routine  and  adverse-event  reporting,  waste  management,  preventive 
maintenance, supportive supervision, and supply chain management with the aim of achieving 
less than 10% stockout nationally; (iii) capacity building of health staff in evidence-based planning 
and  bottom-up  budgeting  for  routine  integrated  outreach  with  an  equity  focus;  (iv)  sex-
disaggregated immunization reporting that is integrated in the broader health information system; 
and (v) evidence generation through nationwide immunization coverage surveys and other 
surveys to assess the quality and equity of vaccine management. The additional financing will 
support the rollout of the national vaccine deployment plans, including the revision of national 
immunization policies and guidelines to include the COVID-19 vaccine; expanded training for 
vaccinators on the COVID-19 vaccine; microplanning to identify and target population segments 
for the COVID-19 vaccine rollout; and supplementary immunization activities for rapid catch-up 
campaigns. It will also enable increased monitoring and surveillance through the proposed

C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
17.  Several development partners have committed to support Pacific island countries’ access 
to COVID-19 vaccines. where UNICEF, WHO, the World Bank, and the governments of Australia 
and New Zealand are represented in COVAX, and supported the pooling of resources toward the 
AMC for the development of a COVID-19 vaccine.24 ADB’s project provides an established 
platform to introduce the COVID-19 vaccine in the four DMCs, which the additional financing can 
help secure. A COVID-19 vaccine will contribute to immunization as a regional public good and 
promote collaboration through pooled procurement. ADB is coordinating regional knowledge 
sharing on the development of COVID-19 vaccines and, as of 16 March 2021, had approved 
about $756 million, including in cofinancing and technical assistance, to support Pacific countries' 
response to the pandemic.25 These initiatives—including the emergency procurement of essential 
medical supplies and equipment, and direct support to multisector COVID-19 preparedness and 
response plans—will complement the proposed introduction of a COVID-19 vaccine in mitigating 
and containing the spread of COVID-19 and accelerating recovery from the pandemic.26

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
21.  The implementation arrangements under the additional financing will remain the same as 
in the original project, i.e., the ministries of finance in Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu will be 
the executing agencies, and the respective MOHs will be the implementing agencies. Project 
management support will be provided by the already-appointed integrated project management 
(IPM) team, which will be expanded to provide additional support. UNICEF will continue to provide 
vaccine and cold chain procurement and expert services.  
 
22.  Under the additional financing, UNICEF will support COVID-19 vaccine procurement, 
national immunization planning, training, and risk communication, while WHO will be engaged to 
support monitoring and safety surveillance. The procurement of vaccines, cold chain equipment, 
and associated services will be carried out in accordance with UNICEF’s Supply Manual and its 
Human Resources Manual.30 The additional financing will support the countries in strengthening 
their vaccine coverage monitoring, reporting, and surveillance by recruiting consultants provided 
through the IPM firm.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE  
 
25.  Through strategic investments in both vaccine procurement and activities to strengthen 
health systems in the overall project, the expected outcome of broader immunization coverage 
and greater efficiency of primary health care will benefit more than 583,700 people across Samoa, 
Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu. Neighboring Pacific countries are likely to benefit from increased 
regional immunization coverage, fewer transboundary infections, and improved surveillance, 
which are all expected to contribute to regional cooperation and integration. 
 
A.  Technical 
 
26.  The additional financing will strengthen the countries’ responses to health emergencies, 
such as the COVID-19 pandemic, by helping supply a vaccine that will reduce the risk of getting 
the life-threatening disease by disrupting the transmission chain and preventing its spread, and 
build a resilient health system to provide rapid access to vaccines. Investments in vaccines and 
immunization programs are established as being a most cost-effective health measure, and are 
timely given that many Pacific countries have remained free of confirmed COVID-19 cases. 
 
27.  UNICEF and WHO will continue to support the four DMCs in (i) updating or revising 
national immunization programs and public health policies; (ii) upgrading cold chain capacities 
and supply chain networks, procurement capacity, information systems, and fiscal management 
capacity in the health sector; and (iii) strengthening the capacity of the respective MOHs. UNICEF 
and WHO have advised that each MOH has sufficient staff and logistics capacity to manage the 
introduction of COVID-19 vaccines.  
 
28.  ADB is closely coordinating with development partners (para. 10) to ensure that financing 
and technical support for the introduction of COVID-19 vaccines are aligned.32  
 
 
32Health coordination meetings include the participation of ADB, Australia, New Zealand, the Pacific Community, 
  
UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank. The Pacific Community, formerly the South Pacific Commission, is an 
international development organization owned and governed by 26 country and territory members, including Samoa, 
Tonga, Tuvalu and Vanuatu.

B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
29.  Economic analysis. Most project resources will be allocated to the procurement of 
vaccines and health infrastructure upgrades (cold chain, health facility assets, and staff training). 
These will translate into better health outcomes by reducing the burden of disease, and into long-
term cost savings and potential economic growth. The project has a pro-poor and equity focus by 
strengthening health services in remote areas. The economic benefits accrue from (i) savings for 
households from less out-of-pocket spending on health care, and (ii) benefits from disability-
adjusted life years saved. Given that the health-related nature of the project makes it difficult to 
quantify the monetary value of project benefits, a cost-effectiveness analysis was carried out. An 
incremental  cost-effectiveness  ratio  (dollars  per  disability-adjusted  life  year  averted)  was 
calculated for each vaccine in each country. The addition of the COVID-19 vaccines to the rollout 
of the other three vaccines (para. 13) remains cost-effective for all four countries.33 
 
30.  Financial analysis. An updated project financial analysis was conducted in accordance 
with ADB guidelines, and the project remains financially sustainable.34 A financial viability analysis 
is not required for projects that do not include revenue-generating activities.  
 
C.  Sustainability 
 
31.  The fiscal conditions in all four DMCs could worsen because of the COVID-19 pandemic, 
but  in  a  review  mission  conducted  in  October  2020  the  governments  confirmed that  their 
counterpart funding remains manageable. The financial sustainability of the project will be sought 
through measures such as factoring in forecast needs for routine vaccines and cold chain 
replenishment in national health budgets, and phasing the financing of vaccine procurement. By 
expanding preventive health care, the project will reduce future health costs. 
 
D.  Governance 
 
32.  Project-related governance risks were assessed in accordance with ADB’s procurement 
and financial management requirements.35 The recruitment of the IPM team with in-country and 
regional procurement specialists will mitigate the risk of MOH staff having limited procurement 
capacity. Complex procurement actions under the project will be undertaken by UNICEF, which 
has extensive experience in global vaccine procurement. The financial management risk rating is 
moderate for Samoa and Tonga, substantial for Tuvalu, and high for Vanuatu. Detailed financial 
management action plans have been developed to manage identified risks and ensure effective 
implementation with the support of the IPM. The IPM will also help conduct independent biannual 
fiduciary reviews, provide targeted technical assistance to develop capacity for ADB procedures 
and financial monitoring, and establish separate project accounts. 
 
33.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the ministries of finance and the ministries of health of Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu. 
The policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 30).

E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
34.  The project is classified gender equity. The additional financing will support the safe 
introduction of a COVID-19 vaccine. This will particularly benefit women who are at increased risk 
of infection because of their roles as health workers (who will be prioritized for the vaccine), other 
frontline workers, and carers. A reduction in mortality from vaccine-preventable diseases will bring 
significant socioeconomic benefits. A revised gender action plan was agreed with the respective 
governments to support the overall project outcome of increasing HPV vaccine coverage for girls 
aged 9–14 years, PCV and rotavirus vaccine coverage for birth cohorts of both sexes, and 
COVID-19 vaccine population coverage targets.36 Other targets include (i) gender-responsive 
microplans, (ii) training for at least 50% of female health providers on introducing and managing 
new vaccines, (iii) gender-responsive community mobilization strategies, (iv) activities to promote 
adolescent  reproductive  health  with  gender  equity  considerations,  and  (v)  nationwide  sex-
disaggregated  immunization  reporting.37  The  additional  financing  will  also  support  sex-
disaggregated vaccine surveillance data and gender-sensitive health promotion activities with a 
focus on hand hygiene and infection control.38 
 
F.  Safeguards 
 
35.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the additional financing will 
retain its original project’s categorization of C for environment, involuntary resettlement, and 
indigenous peoples.39 No physical works will be undertaken, so the additional financing will not 
create adverse environmental impacts. The overall project (i) will fund the management of waste 
from cold chain equipment and biomedical supplies, and support training on waste management; 
and (ii) will not introduce any additional risk to the occupational health and safety of health care 
workers. The overall project will not cause any physical and economic displacement, or affect any 
distinct and vulnerable group of indigenous peoples as defined by ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement. An assessment matrix was prepared, and no mitigation measure is required.40

37.  The Governments of Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu have assured ADB that the 
project's implementation  shall conform  to  all  applicable ADB  requirements,  including  those 
concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and

metadata.Subject:
As a response to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, the governments of Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu have been preparing for the imminent arrival of COVID-19 vaccines, and have requested additional financing from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to further strengthen immunization programs and prepare for the vaccine rollout.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated March 2021 is provided for the ADB regional project 50282-003.
metadata.Title: Systems Strengthening for Effective Coverage of New Vaccines in the Pacific Project under the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility: Report and Recommendation of the President
